comments.raw_text:
User Agent: Mozilla/5.0 (Windows NT 5.1; rv:2.0.1) Gecko/20100101 Firefox/4.0.1
Build ID: 20110413222027

Steps to reproduce:

Attempted to use HTML5 drag and drop to define a custom drop target as seen here:

http://nczonline.net/temp/DragAndDropExample03.htm


Actual results:

When an image is dragged to the drop target, the browser navigated to the image URL. This appears to be a regression of an old bug: https://bugzilla.mozilla.org/show_bug.cgi?id=471438


Expected results:

When the image is dropped, the browser should not have navigated.
comments.creator: webkit@nczonline.net
comments.author: webkit@nczonline.net

comments.raw_text:
Checked in Firefox 3.6, Firefox 4, and Firefox 5, saw the same behavior.

Checked the behavior in IE8, IE9, Chrome, and Safari 5. Could not reproduce.
comments.creator: webkit@nczonline.net

comments.text:
So I'm not sure if this is the bug I'm looking for or if no one reported it. I searched for "drop to navigate". 

Here's two things that this article discusses that can unexpectedly navigate https://textslashplain.com/2020/06/03/avoiding-unexpected-navigation/

- drop to navigate
- backspace to navigate

I can see some telemetry being done on backspace and maybe a user facing preference being made. Opening files and URLs in a new tab when dropped on the page (not on the tab or address bar), makes sense.
comments.author: Poopooracoocoo@outlook.com
comments.creator: Poopooracoocoo@outlook.com
comments.raw_text:
So I'm not sure if this is the bug I'm looking for or if no one reported it. I searched for "drop to navigate". 

Here's two things that this article discusses that can unexpectedly navigate https://textslashplain.com/2020/06/03/avoiding-unexpected-navigation/

- drop to navigate
- backspace to navigate

I can see some telemetry being done on backspace and maybe a user facing preference being made. Opening files and URLs in a new tab when dropped on the page (not on the tab or address bar), makes sense.
